hero_subtitle: how YouTube went from a hobbyist paradise to a whole industry
transcript_content: Hey guys, Jimmy here, welcome to my first YouTube video. I'm going to be very famous and get a lot of money from this, but I don't know how to yet. But hey, check this out, I found this really cool site, where apparently, they offer a course, on how to make a living off YouTube. It's quite expensive but at least you do save the one dollar. So um I definitely want to do this, let's check it out... Let's see what happens
intro_chat_2: [jimmy] I just spent 999$ on your course with my mom's credit card...
intro_chat_4: [jimmy] Can you help me make a lot of money on YouTube?
intro_chat_7: [vivian] Wait! What we CAN do is show you just how Youtube went from an hobby to an industry that makes many people tons of money. We are really good at what we do! We are super trustworthy and we have the best dataset! Check this out...
dataset_subtitle: Manoel Horta Ribeiro and Robert West (2011)
dataset_p1: The YouNiverse dataset is a large collection of English-language YouTube metadata from over 136k channels and 72.9M videos published between May 2005 and October 2019. YouNiverse also comprises channel-level time-series data with weekly subscriber and view counts, as well as a table specifying which videos a set of 449M anonymous users commented on.
sb_p1: The SponsorBlock database is the core of the open-source crowdsourced SponsorBlock browser extension. The extension aims to skip sponsor segments in YouTube videos. Users submit when a sponsor happens from the extension, and the extension automatically skips sponsors it knows about.
dataset_chat_1: [jimmy] Okay, fine. You know what you are doing. So how do I make money?
dataset_chat_2: [kaleb] To know that we know what we know, and that we do not know what we do not know, that is true knowledge...
dataset_chat_5: [daniel] He's trying to say that in order to master something, you need to first understand it. We have researched several questions, just for you, about what the data tell us.
learn_subtitle: Click any question to jump to that section **I KNOW THIS BIT IS A BIT UGLY**
q1_title: How have channels evolved from indie to professional?
q1_desc: What is the adoption curve of sponsorships between different categories?
q2_title: What enabled indie channels to become professional-minded?
q2_desc: At what subscriber thresholds do creators start showing "industry-like" patterns?
q3_title: How does a focus on professionalism affect engagement?
q3_desc: Does the number of views change after channels get sponsors?
section1_title: How have channels evolved from indie to professional?
section1_intro: YouTube grew from 338k uploads in 2008 to over 15.2 million in 2018. This rapid rise changed which categories became more or less common, and how creators approached their content.
dialogue_eddie_ask: Jimmy, what category do you want to explore?
dialogue_eddie_response_2: evolved over time. Check out the full visualization below!
dialogue_compare_ask: Want to compare two categories side by side? Pick Category A and Category B below!
section2_title: What enabled indie channels to become professional-minded?
section3_title: How does a focus on professionalism affect engagement?
